### Project Overview


Species distribution models (SDMs) have become indispensable tools for relating species occurrences to environmental conditions. Most commonly, these models utilize machine learning algorithms to statistically evaluate environmental covariates to determine the relative suitability of locations on the landscape (e.g., [Elith & Leathwick 2009](https://doi.org/10.1146/annurev.ecolsys.110308.120159)). Machine learning is a supervised learning framework; that is, models are fitted to training examples that consist of measured correlates and a desired output value ([Hastie et al. 2009](https://link.springer.com/book/10.1007/978-0-387-84858-7); [James et al. 2013](https://link.springer.com/content/pdf/10.1007/978-1-4614-7138-7.pdf); [Kuhn & Johnson 2013](https://link.springer.com/book/10.1007/978-1-4614-6849-3)). These models are then used in predicting the outcome of novel data. 

While these models are useful at estimating a species range, an extensive amount of literature exists pertaining to the limitations of SDMs (e.g., [Pearson & Dawson 2003]( https://doi.org/10.1046/j.1466-822X.2003.00042.x) ; [Hijmans 2012](https://doi.org/10.1890/11-0826.1); [Melanesi et al. 2019](https://doi.org/10.1002/ece3.5938) ; [Norberg et al. 2019]( https://doi.org/10.1002/ecm.1370)).  Currently these models are limited to static predictors, usually constructed from averaging climate data over extended periods. Deep learning neural networks (DLNN) have been used in other fields of research to interpret time series dynamics and can be used to fit SDMs without averaging or simplifying input data, and enable dynamic processes to better inform the models ([Capinha et al. 2021](https://doi.org/10.1016/j.ecoinf.2021.101252)).

The goal of our study was to expand on the findings in [Capinha et al. (2021)](https://doi.org/10.1016/j.ecoinf.2021.101252) by evaluating the predictive potential of time series deep learning models. We used 30 years of monthly bioclimatic data to predict species distribution for four previously studied, globally invasive species. We then compared four deep-learning architectures to three favored machine learning methods trained on 19 static predictors.

### Methods

#### Software

 We used a combination of R (https://www.r-project.org) and Python (https://www.python.org) for all of our data pre-processing, computations, and graphics. Our time series analysis was performed in Python with Keras (https://keras.io) and  TensorFlow (https://www.tensorflow.org) deep learning suites, and the time series analsyis package,  mcfly ([van Kuppevelt et al. 2020](https://doi.org/10.1016/j.softx.2020.100548)).  We used several R geospatial packages for traditional static modeling procedures (for an in depth tutorial of this, check the official R-Spatial [website](https://rspatial.org/raster/sdm/index.html)).

#### Species data {.tabset .tabset-pills}

We used occurrence records from four previously published SDM studies pertaining to invasive species for our analysis:  Wild Boar (*Sus scrofa* ; [Sales et al. 2017](https://doi.org/10.1111/1365-2656.12721)), Kudzu (*Pueraria montana* ; [Callen & Miller 2015](https://doi.org/10.1111/ddi.12341)), Asian Harlequin ladybird (*Harmonia axyridis* ; [Bidinger et al. 2012](https://doi.org/10.1111/j.1439-0418.2010.01598.x)), and Monk Parakeet (*Myiopsitta monachus* ; [Bohl et al. 2019](https://doi.org/10.1111/jbi.13573)).

In addition to the global invasive models, we reviewed a study pertaining to scarlet monkeyflower (*Erythranthe cardinalis* ; [Angert et al. (2018)](https://doi.org/10.1086/695984)), a native plant to western California and Oregon, United Sates.  In this study, historical occurrences (n = 431) were collected for model training, pseudo-absences  were extracted from  donut-like buffers  with the center/occurrences removed, and tested using field records collected to validate model performance, and to evaluate habitat for potential range expansion. Note, the testing records consist of both presence and true-absences (e.g., P/A modeling). 

We replicated the methods used in [Angert et al. (2018)](https://doi.org/10.1086/695984) for creating our data set:

* Created donut-like buffers around each point ( outer radius = 80km ; inner radius = 600m ) 
* Collect random pseudo-absences from buffer( n = 1000 ). 
* Test models on validation dataset 

Here, the validation data provided consists for 240 observations: 96 presences; and 144 absences.

Ideally, SDMs are built using both presence and absence records; however, absences are often not recorded. A reasonable alternative is to use pseudo-absence or background points, which are data points pulled from areas assumed to be less suitable due to the lack of recorded occurrences (...).  We chose to use two spatial extents for our modeling procedure.  First, we randomly sampled 10,000 terrestrial background points from a global buffer. Next we chose to construct a 100KM buffer around our occurrence points and merged these polygons to create a reduced spatial extent/study region, and then sample an additional 10,000 background points.

#### Bioclimatic covariates

A common procedure when building an SDM is to model the bioclimatic envelope, the geographic space that measures the relationship between species occurrences and regional climate (e.g. [Hutchinson 1957](doi:10.1101/SQB.1957.022.01.039) [Guisan & Zimmermann 2000](https://doi.org/10.1016/S0304-3800(00)00354-9) ; [Pearson et al. 2002](https://doi.org/10.1016/S0304-3800(02)00056-X) ; [Pearson & Dawson 2003]( https://doi.org/10.1046/j.1466-822X.2003.00042.x)). WorldClim ([Fick & Hijmans 2017](https://doi.org/10.1002/joc.5086)), a set of raster files with embedded climate data, is often used in building SDMs, particularly the 19 bioclimatic variables (BIO).  These variables are calculated by using monthly measured precipitation, maximum & minumum temperatures, and site altitude, over a 30 year window (1970-2000 for ver.2 ). 

We used the BIO variables for our static machine learning models. For our time series models, we used the raw monthly measurements for our time steps over the same time frame ( 360 time steps) These rasters can also be found on the WorldClim website (https://worldclim.org). 

#### Algorithms

There are 4 deep learning architectures provided by Keras that we used for our model building:

1. Convolutional neural networks (CNN)
2. Recurrent neural networks (RNNs)
3. Residual networks (ResNet)
4. Inception time networks 

All of these methods are extensions on the multi-layer perceptron, usually referred to as Artificial Neural Networks (ANN).  Traditionally, ANNs are feed-forward, have a fully connected network, and trained with back propagation and/or gradient descent learning algorithms. ANNs are especially helpful when computations are needed on large, complex data sets; however, this sort of power also leads to over-fitting. This is because the data are transformed using smoothing kernels at several steps within the learning procedure. The deep-learning architectures mentioned above were created to overcome this  by studying the raw data patterns directly.  Also, DLNNs are not entirely feed-forward; hat is, they tend to learn and self-correct at various steps in the internal processing instead after each learning iteration or epoch.   

For comparitive purposes, we used 3 popular and highly-productive machine learning algorithms for our static data analysis: Gradient Booosting Machines (GBM; e.g.,[Friedman 2001]( https://doi.org/10.1890/0012-9658(2007)88[243:BTFEMA]2.0.CO;2) [De'Ath 2007]( https://doi.org/10.1890/0012-9658(2007)88[243:BTFEMA]2.0.CO;2) ; [Elith et al. 2008](https://doi.org/10.1111/j.1365-2656.2008.01390.x) );  Maximum Entropy (MaxEnt; [Phillips et al. 2006](https://doi.org/10.1016/j.ecolmodel.2005.03.026) ; [Elith et al. 2011](https://doi.org/10.1111/j.1472-4642.2010.00725.x) ) ; and  Random Forest (RF;  [Brieman 2001](https://link.springer.com/article/10.1023/A:1010933404324) ; [Cutler et al. 2007](https://doi.org/10.1890/07-0539.1) ; [Evans et al. 2011](https://link.springer.com/chapter/10.1007/978-1-4419-7390-0_8) )



#### Modeling framework 

##### Time series deep learning 

For each species, we collected a bootstrap-sample of occurrences to match the number of background points, and  compiled our presence and background points into a a single, balanced data frame. We then extracted the values of each covariate at each time step for these points. Next we partitioned our data into several groups for the modeling procedure:

* train data set for candidate models (~35%; **At**) 
* validation data set for candidate models (~35%; **Av**) 
* At + Av, or train data set for selected model (~70%;  **Bt**) 
* validation data set for selecting # of epochs (~15%; **Bv**) 
* final reporting of classification performance (~15%; **T**) 

Once the data were partitioned the modeling procedure was as follows:

1. Create 5 randomly assembled models of each architecture (20 total candidate models).
    + Candidate models are built using **At** 
    + Evaluated using **Av** and classification accuracy
    + Run four epochs for each model  
    + Evaluated using classification accuracy 
2. Choose the best model, or the candidate with highest accuracy score.
3. Run 50 epochs 
    + In each epoch, the model is built using **Bt**
    + Evaluate model with **Bv**, calaculate accuracy and Area Under the receiver operating Curve (AUC)   
    + Each epoch updates internal parameters to improve model performance
4. Choose epoch model with best AUC as final model
5. Test model predictions using **T**
6. Calculate the AUC 


For the Monkeyflower models, we used a slightly different approach.  The testing set in the [Angert et al. (2018)](https://doi.org/10.1086/695984) study was used for **T**.  We then partitioned the sample from the training points to to match the 35:35:15:15 used in the other models.

##### Static machine learning 

Three static model sampling architectures were used for comparison:

1. Balanced-BIO 
    +  We used the same samples in **Bt** and **T** DLNNs to build and test our static models. The 19 BIO covariates were used in these models
2. Imbalanced-BIO
    + The common approach of taking the relatively small set of presence points and a significantly larger sample of background points and partitioning them into a train and test set.  Here we split both our occurrence  and background data 70:30 (train:test).  The 19 BIO covariates were used in these models
3. Balanced-WC
    + Similar to the Balanced-BIO, except we used the 4 WorldClim variables. We used altitude rsater and created three rasters for static covariates:  maximum measured temperature; minimum measured temperature; and averaged monthly precipitation.  

For all three architectures, AUC was calculated for model comparison.
